checkpoint_notes.C2: Supreme Court packed with loyalists; rubber-stamps executive
checkpoint_notes.C5: Rule by decree; emergency powers extended indefinitely

narrative: Venezuela 2016 represents the critical transition from competitive authoritarianism to electoral authoritarianism. Despite opposition winning the National Assembly in 2015 by a landslide, Maduro used the Supreme Court to systematically nullify legislative actions. The recall referendum—constitutionally mandated—was blocked through procedural manipulation. This shows how formal democratic institutions can be maintained while democratic substance is eliminated. The key mechanism was court capture combined with electoral council capture: elections could occur, but outcomes could be managed. By 2016, the electoral path to change was effectively blocked.

Gamboa, Laura. 'Opposition at the Margins: Strategies against the Erosion of Democracy in Colombia and Venezuela.' Comparative Politics 49, no. 4 (2017): 457-477
Levitsky, Steven and Lucan Way. 'The Rise of Competitive Authoritarianism.' Journal of Democracy 13, no. 2 (2002): 51-65
comparison_guidance: Venezuela 2016 demonstrates how legislative opposition can be neutralized through court capture even after winning elections. Use this baseline to assess scenarios where courts are being positioned to override electoral outcomes. The electoral_exit_blocked flag is critical—it indicates that the normal democratic correction mechanism has been disabled. This is often the point of no return for peaceful transitions.
